text: quasimodo hi everyone Anthony Fantana
here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for your review of the new
Quasimodo album yes sir
whatever Lorde coifs Quasimodo aka
Madlib a producer multi-instrumentalist
DJ and rapper hey guy who was infamous
incredibly prolific he's really got more
LPS than most with projects like
yesterday's new quintet as well as mad
villain he's also released numerous
tracks under a slew of other names -
like the beat conductor loop Digga monk
hughes and of course it's not enough
that this man just makes his ton of
music on his own he needs to come up
with an alter-ego to release more music
hence Quasimodo now this new release is
kind of a collection an album a bit of a
compilation it's 12 tracks which the
creation of spans about 12 years dating
back to the release of Quasimodo's first
full-length LP the unseen an album that
ton of people who are in the underground
hip hop praise the hell out of and for
good reason and even though there are
some new cuts on this project
there are also songs on here that were
previously released on an EP as well as
other singles so it's not like this new
release is 100% fresh though the cuts
that have been previously put out are
kind of rarities you know you're not
going to come across them just anywhere
one track after another on this thing
involves libs treid márk gritty jazzy
blunted hip hop production which is
funky as well and of course all of these
beats are graced with his verses which
he's known for taking the pitch of them
and shifting it up if you took mad live
and Shrunk him down to the size of a
gnome this is essentially the voice that
you would imagine coming out of him
rapping and it's a kind of funny thing
to hear in an age where the chopped and
screwed sound is so prevalent in a lot
of the hip-hop you hear it's almost
refreshing in a way to hear somebody
shifting their vocals up in pitch now
with 32 minutes long even though yes or
whatever is not as varied or as epic or
as expansive as the unseen it is still a
really fun listen even though Madlib
doesn't take a lot of risks between the
songs on this
the beats he brings to the table are
colorful they're classy they got a snap
to them like the song planned attack
which has these watery guitar samples
left and right the kicks on this thing
are deep as hell the snares are really
thin and crisp there's a touch of reverb
on there Quasimodo is rapping on this
track sort of trading places with mad
libs lower not pitched vocal they're
these really catchy DJ cuts flying in
and out of the track to it is the
perfect recipe for a head Bob I'm loving
the song broad factor on here as well in
terms of the rhythm hiding behind all of
the samples it's a little similar to the
track I just mentioned it's actually
similar to a lot of tracks on this LP
but Madlib is good at taking these very
similar grooves and colouring them with
very very different samples to the point
where each song really has its own vibe
now there are points on this album that
are a little underwhelming or for
whatever reason they just don't stick
like be very obvious obvious and
repetitive vocal sampling on the track
seasons change or mad libs kind of
underwhelming verses on tracks like
brothers can't see me or specifically
the front mad libs rap style really
tends to be sort of monotone somewhat
lifeless in a way and hearing his voice
pitched down to its normal pitch it
actually is a bit of a hindrance since
his voice doesn't exactly read too well
against the Basie production there's
also the very short track on your
Youngblood which I guess I'm not too
enthralled with but I honestly do think
if you were to take most of the tracks
out of the context of this album and
just listen to them on their own that
they wouldn't be that impressive to your
normal hip-hop fan still even though
there isn't you know a hot hot track on
this LP yes sir is is far from a boring
album because it really gains power from
how all of these short tracks work
together as a listening experience
there's a serious power to the odd
analog crackle of these tracks as they
weave together into this gogo dodo like
hip hop scape this is essentially the
rap games answer to wacky land with all
the Warped samples and synthesizers and
ear candy effects there is something
that is truly psychedelic about
yes or whatever as far as verses go
there are definitely some lyrical
nuggets on this thing the song catching
the vibe has Madlib talking about his
music career versus the music career of
more mainstream hip hop artists who sort
of seem to be overnight sensations and
turn out to be duds a few years down the
road Quasimodo also has shots fired
other rappers on the song planned attack
there are also flaky people touchdown on
a verse in this thing the song spark
dolla is a bit of an ode to marijuana
and the track green power in a way is is
actually kind of sad it's one of the few
moments where Mad Libs voice to me
carries a completely different tone to
it there are a lot of rap albums and
mixtapes out there that I have heard
that deliver more monotone flow and it
completely turns me off however this
project really is sort of the exception
to that rule in a sense because this
weird monotone flow along with some of
the vocal effects really plays into
building up this sort of hypnotic
textured alluring funny entertaining and
seductive aesthetic that Madlib pulls
together on yes or whatever even though
this is an amazing release it really is
a tribute to Mad Libs
talents that he can grab a series of
tracks that are pretty much just a loose
collection of ideas slap them on an
album and they end up this friggin
cohesive I'm feeling a decent strong
seven on this thing if you've given it a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it
hate it why what do you think I should
review next and that's it this review is
my opinion if you don't like it here's a
straw I want to give a shout out to Eric
Andre Pye you and albums that get
releases in the UK way before they get
released in the US and and I can't even
get a chance to hear them or review them
from makes me angry also I want to give
a shout out to the rain that's happening
outside right now thunderstorm only the
strong subscribe all mistakes were
intentional Anthony Fantana
quasimodo yes or whatever
forever
